subtopics.title: Phylogenetics
subtopics.description: Learn about evolution through Phylogenetics, the study of evolutionary relationships among groups of organisms.

editorial_board.name: Peter van Heusden
editorial_board.bio: Research at the South African National Bioinformatics Institute

materials.title: Phylogenetics - Back to basics
questions: What information can I get from a phylogenetic tree?
How do I estimate a phylogeny?
How can I tell whether the phylogeny is reliable?
objectives: Describe the basic concepts behind phylogenetic trees and how they are made
Read and interrogate a phylogeny encountered in the literature
Use standard tools to align a set of molecular sequences
Assess the quality of a molecular sequence alignment and be able to modify it appropriately for phylogenetic analysis
Use standard tools to estimate a phylogenetic tree based on a set of aligned molecular sequences
Assess the reliability of estimated phylogenies with bootstrapping
Explore phylogenetic signal using phylogenetic networks

workflows.name: Tree Building (imported from uploaded file)
workflows.title: Tree Building (imported from uploaded file)

materials.title: Tree thinking for tuberculosis evolution and epidemiology
questions: What information can I get from a phylogenetic tree?
How do I estimate a phylogeny?
objectives: Understand the basic concepts behind phylogenetic trees, as applied to *Mycobacterium tuberculosis*
Be able to read and interrogate a phylogeny encountered in the literature

materials.title: Identifying tuberculosis transmission links: from SNPs to transmission clusters
objectives: Calculate pairwise SNP distances between MTB samples
Identify transmission clusters based on SNP distances
Study the emergence and spread of drug resistance based on transmission analysis.
key_points: Clustering is a useful tool to detect transmission links between patients and oubreak investigation.
Clustering can be used to investigate the transmission of certain traits, like drug resistance.
Clustering does not provide information about particular transmission events nor their directionality (who infected whom).
Clustering is very much influenced by sampling. Lower sampling proportions and shorter sampling timeframes lead to lower clustering rates that shoud not be confounded with lack of transmission.
